channel.title: [Tutorial] Inline for loops in Python
channel.description:
https://www.jamesmonger.com/post/inline-for-loops-in-python.html
Python is a language that has the potential to make pieces of code very short. There are lots of tricks to turn lengthy code operations that would require multiple lines in other languages into a neat, single line snippet. While I was working on an upcoming tutorial on web scraping, I had an array of HTML tags and I wanted to get an array containing only the text of the tags. My first solution was a bulky one but I managed to quickly turn it into something more Python-esque.
https://www.jamesmonger.com/post/inline-for-loops-in-python.html Looking for feedback as usual.

item.title: [Tutorial] Inline for loops in Python
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“argv, post:10, topic:551853”]Seems much neater:

$_ = $_->string for @titles; print join " - ", 0..10;[/quote]

Wow… It’s been a while since I’ve seen anyone use Perl.

Read full topic

item.title: [Tutorial] Inline for loops in Python
item.dc:creator: @argv argv
item.description:
@argv wrote:

Seems much neater:

$_ = $_->string for @titles; print join " - ", 0..10;

item.title: [Tutorial] Inline for loops in Python
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

Bowser jr:

I don’t see why you would want to use map here.

you would use map to convert the list of ints into a list of strs to use join.

Read full topic

item.title: [Tutorial] Inline for loops in Python
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:1, topic:551853”]https://www.jamesmonger.com/post/inline-for-loops-in-python.html

[quote]Python is a language that has the potential to make pieces of code very short. There are lots of tricks to turn lengthy code operations that would require multiple lines in other languages into a neat, single line snippet.

While I was working on an upcoming tutorial on web scraping, I had an array of HTML tags and I wanted to get an array containing only the text of the tags. My first solution was a bulky one but I managed to quickly turn it into something more Python-esque.[/quote]

https://www.jamesmonger.com/post/inline-for-loops-in-python.html

Looking for feedback as usual.[/quote]

The feature you are describing in this article are called array/object comprehensions. They are coming to PHP 7 and ECMAScript 6 (new version of JavaScript).

Read full topic

item.title: [Tutorial] Inline for loops in Python
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:2, topic:551853”]Stop bashing other languages for the need of writing lots of code/lines to achieve something similar.

print(0 to 9 mkString " - ") A lot shorter in scala (21 chars shorter.) So don’t think Python is unique in that aspect, and I’m sure Java 8 can produce something similarly short.

To criticize your content, it seems incomplete. To be of any value you should include more information about for loops, iteration and lambda functions.[/quote]

I wasn’t bashing other languages! I just think that as a whole Python can produce shorter code than the other languages I’m used to (C#, PHP, Java)

Read full topic

item.title: [Tutorial] Inline for loops in Python
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Stop bashing other languages for the need of writing lots of code/lines to achieve something similar.

print(0 to 9 mkString " - ") A lot shorter in scala (21 chars shorter.) So don’t think Python is unique in that aspect, and I’m sure Java 8 can produce something similarly short.

To criticize your content, it seems incomplete. To be of any value you should include more information about for loops, iteration and lambda functions.

Read full topic
